This job is good for high school students who need money and don't know any better. It was my mistake taking the job in the first place and I'm counting down the days until my last shift.

job_title: Banquets Red Coat in Louisville, KY
pros: Good benefits, great employee discounts, free meals in the Banquets department
cons:
Let me start by saying I was very optimistic coming into this position. The Marriott seemed like a great company to work for and that they really cared about the individual. I am now a firm believer that there is no such culture or belief system at a corporate business in general, unless you're lucky enough to work for Google. 

During my interview process, I was very transparent about being a college student and that I would be in school full time, but also very well capable of working a full-time position as well and there would be restrictions in my schedule because of my classes. I made this known to the HR girl, my direct supervisor, and HER direct supervisor during my interview because I know companies can be wary of hiring college students and didn't want to waste anyone's time. I repeated this several times because I've experienced that there is definitely a prejudice against college students in the work place (as in no one wants to hire them unless it's part-time) and have had companies go through the motions during the interview only to find out they don't want to work around a college schedule. I said that exact sentence to my manager during my interview. So with that being said, everyone seemed very accepting of my schedule. Then I not only gave my exact availability to the HR supervisor, but my manager as well on my FIRST DAY. That part is important, because after a full week of working for them, I receive a call from HR saying management does not want to move forward with my employment because of my availability restraints, A FULL WEEK LATER. The availability that I told three different people on two different occasions. And if that wasn't enough, I was informed that I would not be reimbursed for the $100 uniform I bought specifically for this job even though i was told if I gave management my receipt they would refund me. So I literally lost money working for these people. I've now turned down 6 other jobs for this one, I'm in a new city with no employment or means of money, I may lose my chance for in-state tuition (anyone who's been to an out-of-state university knows what a big deal this is), and my fiance and I have to hope that we can live off his med school loans all because management couldn't communicate earlier that my availability wasn't okay for them. I've never experienced such unprofessionalism, lack of accountability, or lack of respect for other's time than I have with this company, which is surprising considering their size.

pros: Everyone on-site was very informative and nice. The bedbugs are probably gone.
cons:
This is absolutely a sales job; it doesn't matter that you aren't making cold calls.  You will be talking nonstop -- and I mean nonstop, I was taking well over 100 calls daily when I quit -- to customers who do not understand pricing in the hospitality industry.  A lot of in-house information (like about parking costs, this was the worst) is not kept up to date or contradicts itself. Explaining why a hotel room often has a different cost depending on the day and still making the sale is one of the easier parts of the job.  Unless you're talking with someone whose loved one is coming in for surgery and you have to explain that even though the hotel has availability, the hospital rate is sold out because Ariana Grande is in town.  

You aren't selling leggings and can openers. You are going to hear people cry because you can't help them find somewhere to stay in an emergency.  I worked here during and after Hurricane Matthew, Hurricane Harvey, and a few other natural disasters.  Some of those calls still honestly haunt me.  I was told to prepare for obscene crank callers, or the occasional person who would call in and claim they were going to end their life.  Those happen.  I was not prepared to tell a dying person that they couldn't stay with their family at a property that held a lot of sentimental value to them unless they prepaid an overinflated three night minimum because a there's a football game that weekend. 

The emotional burnout was awful.  This is an absolutely terrible job if you're an empathetic or compassionate person.  I remember more than one person telling me they coped with it by just assuming everyone is lying by default. I couldn't.  I laugh at the commercials on TV now because I know how deceptive the "we care" brand is.  Trust me, Marriott corporate doesn't care at all.  Look online for all of the employee strikes in the last few years, and the furloughed workers due to COVID-19 who don't qualify for unemployment. 

I was still successful at the job, consistently exceeded sales quotas, and regularly got a monthly bonus when I worked at the Solon center. The best advice I can give a current/potential employee is that your biggest competition is online travel sites. Get in the habit of telling a guest to check their exact travel dates when they're looking at an external website.  If they're seeing $60 on Expedia compared to your $300, that is almost always why.  Also, let me tell you in advance that a doctor's note will not excuse an abscence. This job is a nightmare if you have a chronic condition and need maintenance care.  I'm now fighting an uphill battle with a disability claim because I was doing wound care in the on-site bathroom instead of going to the doctor due to the inflexible scheduling.

I'd like to echo another reviewer and say the cubicles can be absolutely disgusting.  People are told not to eat but they do it anyway. I'm not kidding when I say I walked by someone eating a bucket of chicken from KFC, and overheard a coworker telling a guest to hold so she could chew her chips.  Bring disinfectant wipes.  Your cubicle will still be covered in crumbs, but they help clean up the.. rest.  There is no enforcement of company policy.  I don't understand why, but when I worked there, the only thing management was allowed to do was send a strongly worded e-mail asking people to stop eating or spraying their perfume/cologne in the closed space.  

The people were great!  The job was an absolute nightmare.  I don't even think I would recommend this job to a robot.  I don't mean a metaphorical robot, I mean an actual robot made of metal.
